text:
Zapier, Make, and n8n aren't going anywhere.

But here's the uncomfortable truth:

If drag-and-drop is all you know, you're bringing a bicycle to a Formula 1 race.

Here's the shift:

OLD: You connect boxes together.
→ Trigger → Action → Action → Output
→ You design every step manually
→ If it breaks, you fix it manually
→ It does EXACTLY what you told it. Nothing more.

NEW: You describe the outcome.
→ An AI agent designs the architecture
→ Writes the code, connects the database, handles errors
→ Deploys, maintains, and improves itself
→ Spawns other agents to run parallel tasks

This isn't future talk. I've been building this way for months.

Last week I set up a system that:
→ Scrapes industry news every 24 hours
→ Summarizes with AI
→ Stores in a searchable knowledge base
→ Surfaces insights on demand

No boxes. No drag-and-drop. One prompt.

Workflows automate tasks.
Agents automate decisions.

Both have a place. But if you want to 10x your output in 2026:

Learn to build agents, not just workflows.

What's one workflow you'd love to turn into something that runs itself? 👇
authorHeadline: Top-100 UK Entrepreneur, Teddy AI | Proven Systems to grow your business. AI Expert, Speaker, Educator.

text:
You don't need another course, tutorial, or free resource.

You need an action with a deadline.

I've seen this pattern so many times now.

You want to start something new.

So you buy a course or get a free resource.

Watch all the modules. Take notes. Try it once, maybe twice.

Feel like you're making progress.

But months go by, and you haven't actually built or shared anything.

You keep jumping to the next "new" thing without mastering the one you're already on.

So try this instead:

Pick one small problem. Give yourself a week. 

And just build something — even if it's ugly.

Then share it. Publicly. Before it's ready.

It breaks. You fix it. 

It breaks again. You fix it again. 

And somewhere in that mess, you actually learn.

Courses teach you concepts.

Building teaches you skills.

Sharing in public teaches you both — faster.

What's something you've been meaning to build or share?

text:
Most people overcomplicate AI automation. Here are the only 5 that actually matter:

I've spent 7+ years building systems for my own businesses. And I keep coming back to the same ones.

Not the fancy stuff. Not random fancy AI agents. Not voice bots.

These:

1. Lead response: Speed wins. Replying in 5 minutes instead of 5 hours 
changes everything. 

The first to respond usually wins the deal.

2. Email follow-up: Most people don't buy on the first touch. 

Consistent follow-up is boring. It's also where the money is.

3. Reporting: If you can't see it, you can't fix it. 

One dashboard that shows what matters beats 10 tools you never check.

4. Onboarding: First impressions stick. 

A smooth onboarding keeps customers longer than any feature ever will.

5. Content repurposing: One YouTube video becomes 7 posts. 

One podcast becomes 10 clips. Leverage compounds.

Everything else? Nice to have.

I wasted months chasing complex AI systems while ignoring these fundamentals.

Start boring. Get fancy later.

text:
I've coached 5,000+ entrepreneurs on AI.

One mistake keeps showing up.

They start with tools.

"What AI should I use?"
"Is Claude better than GPT?"
"Should I learn n8n or Make?"

Wrong questions.

The right question is: what's broken?

What's eating your time? 
What keeps you up at 3 AM?
What's costing you money? 
What makes you want to throw your laptop out the window?

Start there.

Then work backwards to the tool.

I've seen people spend 3 months learning automation platforms. 

Building workflows for problems they don't have. 

Chasing shiny tools because X, Instagram, or YouTube said so.

Meanwhile, the actual bottleneck — the thing killing their business — sits untouched.

Here's the fix:

Write down your 3 biggest time drains this week. 

Not "I should automate email" vibes. 

Actual pain. Actual hours lost.

Then ask: how can AI solve this?

If yes, now you pick the tool.

If no, stop trying to automate it.

Tools are easy. Finding the right problem is hard.

text:
The Claude Code creator just shared how he actually uses it.

C → Configure a CLAUDE.md file (Boris's team shares one in git)

text:
'New' is overrated.

When I founded my last business I thought I had to do something NEW.

And we did, and were rewarded for it.

However, I've since realised that working at the alter of new is inefficient.

The CEO of Zynga poker BLEW UP his business following the 'Validated-Improved-New' methodology.

You're far better off:
✔️ Find out what's already working (validated)
✔️ Do that thing better (improve)
✔️ Add something personal (new)

Add your personal flare to it.

This applies to content ideas, hooks, business models - everything.

I love new, but there's definitely a strategy of what you decide to innovate on.

Last year I was at the Skool games (lots of super successful online people)

One person had made $50,000/mo from LinkedIN (not typical)

I asked him to show me 'click-by-click' everything he did

Surprisingly, it was actually very simple.

My biggest takeaway?

All the things to innovate on, funnels is not one of them.

My biggest lesson: Spend a lot of intellectual capital on innovation, but do it on the high leverage areas not places where you're re-inventing the wheel

I've just released a full video on AI audits and the proven funnel.

Link to the FULL video in the comments 👇

text:
The Triple-E Framework makes automations PROFITABLE.

I don't build a single operating system without it.

Most agencies get these the wrong way around.

When building AI Audits, this framework will:

✔️ Show what to focus on FIRST
✔️ Structure your thinking
✔️ Speed up execution

1️⃣ Enhance 
Look at your biggest profit centers - how can AI systems accelerate or scale what's already working?

2️⃣ Eliminate
What are all of the Boring, repetitive, and administrative tasks that happen in the business? Automate them.

3️⃣ Expand
What new products, services, or profit centers can we create using AI systems?

TL;DR:

Enhance (better) is first, eliminate (remove) is second, and expand (new) is last

We thought thinking of NEW or Shiny...

Make what's already profitable, more profitable.

text:
Every tech expert talks about AI automations. 

Few actually understand how it works in practice.

This is 80% of AI Automation in practice:

1️⃣ Business Value First
Prioritise simple solutions that solve high-value business problem
Example: Lead generation flow + email sequence

2️⃣ Simplicity > Complexity
Customers don't care how many nodes your workflows have

3️⃣ Test-Driven Dev (TDD)
Test every module individually before moving on (save time)

4️⃣ HTTP Requests 
Access the full capabilities of any API not supported by pre-built nodes
Example: Copy an API's curl request to set this up

5️⃣ Webhook Triggers
Activate your scenarios from external endpoints.
Example: Use ClickUp/Paperform/whatsapp to push data directly into your flow

6️⃣ Structured Prompting
Specify the output of your LLM.
Example: JSON structured outputs. 

7️⃣ Conditional Logic
Use Filter or Switch nodes to efficiently route data based on rules.
Example: If lead budget is $10,000, route to the node X

8️⃣ Data Manipulation
Clean and transform data fields before they are sent to downstream systems.
Example: First name, second name, dates, remove information, etc.

9️⃣ Determinism vs. Probabilism
Do not use AI agents for everything
Example: if it's the same set of outputs in every scenario, use code over agents

Drop a comment below with the one thing you think everybody misses 👇

♻️ Repost to help your network achieve success.

text:
99% are still using RAG incorrectly.

Get it right and you'll 10X your performance.

Getting it wrong can be expensive, illegal, or sloppy.

Here are 3 principles you need to know.

1️⃣ Search Type is EVERYTHING

Choose between Semantic or Lexical.

Semantic = meaning and context (great for FAQs) 
Lexical = exact word matching (essential for legal/compliance) 

Think of it like searching for a house. Semantic is "find me a cozy 3-bedroom in a good neighbourhood" (vibes). Lexical is "find me 123 Oak Street" (exact address). 

Hybrid checks both.

This can have HUGE impacts. 

For example, If a contract lawyer uses semantic search they may not get the actual wording of the clause.

---

2️⃣ Context Control

When we store your data (vectorisation) we do this in chunks.

RAG finds the most relevant chunks for the query.

How many neighbouring chunks we bring back is the context.

This is like taking a photo. 

Neighbouring chunks = 1 is a tight headshot

Neighboring chunks = 10 is a wide-angle group photo. 

Sometimes you need to see just the face. Sometimes you need to see who's standing next to them.

If you had a LONG compliance section of a contract, you'd need more neighbouring chunks (or fewer total chunks).

---

3️⃣ RAG Diagnostic 

Testing is everything.

Like a mechanic test-driving your car before tuning it. 

You need to see how it actually performs under real conditions, not just assume the default settings work.

The more you scrutinise the system, the better the results.

---

text:
AI Automation is oversaturated.

There's no point learning it.

You've heard this 1,000 times.

This couldn't be further from the truth.

My Dentist recently asked me if I knew what ChatGPT was

I told her that I've never heard of it.

Degree educated, intelligent and only JUST finding out about AI.

Moreover, only ~1% of ChatGPT users pay for PLUS.

It's easy to think that AI and automation is saturated.

You see it every time you log into LinkedIn, YouTube, or Instagram.

It isn't.

We no longer live in a world where knowledge is the bottleneck.

30 years ago, If you wanted to know something it was the library or It's finding a physical expert.

Speed and execution are the only things that matter now.

The difference between AI natives and non is starting to show.

In 5 years, the differences will be unbelievable.
